As someone, who has published a textbook on sharks published over a hundred papers, and many of them on the behavior of sharks.  Who is known as "Dr. Hammerhead".  This person has nothing to fear.  The great and scalloped hammerheads have pointed teeth in at least one jaw, for seizing and pulling into the mouth fishes, squid, and (in the case of the great hammerhead), rays.  They don't eat humans with their relatively small mouths per body length.

The only danger would be if the person in the raft approached the hammerhead directly and rapidly, and did not heed its performance of a warning, or agonistic display.  The shark might then inflict a wound, without removing flesh.  This was shown by a physician, David Baldridge, who noted that a boy with over a hundred and fifty stiches needed to close his wound, had no flesh removed, and wrote a scientific paper, entitled:  "Shark attack: feeding or fighting."

context: I've been a padi certified diver since 2000. I've done dives from Australia to north carolina. I've never once felt in any kind of mortal danger from marine life. Some are naturally inquisitive, like the banded sea snake and some shark species. Sgt major fish are hilariously aggressive, but I digress. Surfers and the like are sometimes mistaken for prey because of the way they look from underneath. Basically, we aren't on anything's menu down there. I'd be much more nervous seeing a moose.
